name: jug
description: Large, easy to grab holds, held with entire hand(s) while requiring minimal energy. A climberâ€™s best friend

name: sloper
description: These tend to have no lip or edge. Needs complete friction, and so requires as much surface area of the hand as possible.

name: crimp
description: Generally small, thin climbing holds. Found on more advanced routes due to a greater need for strength and solid technique.

name: pinch
description: Require the thumb on the opposite side of the hold to create a strong squeezing force. Usually requires the greatest amount of strength.

name: pocket
description: Holes that allow for 1 to 3 fingers combinations. Various depth and textures.

name: side pull
description: When a hold is oriented sideways away from the climber, forcing the climber to use a horizontal direction of force (vs gravity).

name: undercling
description: When holds are oriented upside down, forcing the climber to turn their palms upward.

name: smear
description: When placing the foot on a part of the wall with no actual foothold. By placing the ball of the foot on the wall and putting as much pressure as possible.

name: toe hook
description: Placing the top of the foot on a hold, and putting (by pulling) as much pressure as possible.

name: heel hook
description: Placing a heel on a hold, and putting (by pulling) as much pressure as possible.

name: foot
description: Placing the tips of the feet on usually small holds.

name: ledge/rail
description: Similar to crimps/incuts but much larger. Usually wide enough to fit four fingers or two hands. Common in outdoor rock climbing

name: incut
description: Small jugs that provide a very solid handhold. Generally deep enough for up to the second knuckle. Finger jugs

name: volumes
description: Common in indoor climbing gyms, and can be used no matter which routeis being climbed.

name: gaston
description: When a hold is rotated and oriented toward the climber, requiring an opposing outward push.
